hp.source: Honda official specs, Car and Driver

curb_weight.source: Honda specs - 2,577 lbs (1,170 kg) for 1998 model

zero_to_sixty.source: Car and Driver 1997 test: 6.6s; average sources: 6.2-6.6s

braking_60_0.source: Modern Racer/Acura World: 115-116 ft; C&D 1997: 164 ft (wet?)

lateral_g.source: Car and Driver: 0.88g; Modern Racer: 0.89g; Acura World: 0.91g

value.notes: Honda reliability keeps costs low. Budget for specialty insurance and secure storage.

maintenance_cost_index.source: Honda B-series engines are known for reliability and low maintenance

insurance_notes.value: Standard insurance may not provide adequate coverage. Recommend Hagerty, Grundy, or American Collectors Insurance for agreed-value coverage. High theft rates increase premiums.

platform_cost_tier.source: Prices have appreciated beyond enthusiast tier into collector territory

market_position.value: The Integra Type R has transitioned from affordable enthusiast car to collectible. Clean, low-mile examples now command six-figure prices. Market peaked in 2021-2022 but remains strong.

brand.source: Honda's luxury division for US market

country.source: Built in Japan, imported to US

years.source: Note: 1999 model year not offered in US market

tier.source: Current prices place it in collector tier

generation_code.source: Honda internal designation for third-gen Integra coupe

heritage.value: The Integra Type R brought Honda's racing DNA to America. With a hand-ported B18C5 engine revving to 8,400 RPM, seam-welded chassis, limited-slip differential, and weight savings throughout, it set the standard for front-wheel-drive performance. Honda's Red Badge 'Type R' treatment was legendary in Japan - hand-assembly, race-derived components, and uncompromising focus. The USDM ITR was the first Type R sold in America, bringing that philosophy to our market. Only ~4,000 units were sold in the US (1997-2001), making it quite rare.
heritage.source: Acura Info Center, Honda press releases

design_philosophy.value: Honda's Type R philosophy: remove weight, increase precision, pursue perfection. Every component was scrutinized for weight savings - lighter glass, reduced sound deadening, aluminum hood. The result was a 2,577 lb car that felt telepathic. The mantra was 'racing technology for the road.'

motorsport_history.value: The DC2 Type R dominated SCCA World Challenge Touring Car Championship. RealTime Racing won driver championships in 1997 (Kleinubing), 1998 (Galati), 2000 (Kleinubing), 2001 (Kleinubing), and 2002 (Cunningham). Acura won Manufacturers' Championships in 1998, 1999, 2000, and 2002. The Integra Type R became the most successful model in World Challenge Touring Car history.
motorsport_history.source: RealTime Racing official history, SCCA records

score_sound.source: B18C5 VTEC crossover is legendary but not as aggressive as larger engines

score_interior.source: Spartan, race-focused interior with Recaro seats but dated by modern standards

score_track.source: Excellent handling but limited power compared to modern track cars

score_value.source: Current prices are prohibitive for most buyers

score_driver_fun.source: Widely considered one of the most engaging FWD cars ever

perf_power_accel.source: 195hp is modest; acceleration relies on keeping revs high

perf_grip_cornering.source: Excellent chassis balance and grip for its era

perf_track_pace.source: Competitive in its class at track days

perf_drivability.source: Requires high revs for performance; not lazy to drive

perf_reliability_heat.source: B-series handles heat well; stock cooling adequate

perf_sound_emotion.source: VTEC crossover at 6,100 RPM is emotional

engine_character.value: The B18C5 is one of Honda's finest VTEC engines. It produces 195 hp at 8,000 RPM—the highest specific output of any naturally aspirated production engine at the time (108 hp/liter). VTEC engagement at 6,100 RPM transforms the character. Below VTEC, it's a normal Honda. Above, it screams to 8,400 RPM with an intensity that must be experienced. The engine rewards being driven hard and loves to rev.

transmission_feel.value: The close-ratio 5-speed is perfectly matched to the engine. Short throws, precise gates, satisfying engagement. Cable-actuated shifter provides direct feedback. Final drive ratio of 4.40 keeps the engine in the powerband. Widely considered one of the best manual transmissions ever made.

chassis_dynamics.value: The ITR chassis is legendary. Double-wishbone suspension front and rear, seam-welded body for rigidity, and perfectly tuned geometry. Despite front-wheel-drive, it rotates willingly, communicates clearly, and rewards aggressive driving. The lightweight, stiff shell creates an experience that many RWD cars can't match.

steering_feel.value: Hydraulic power steering with exceptional feedback and precision. You feel everything through the wheel. Quick ratio provides immediate response. No electric assist means pure mechanical connection. Considered a benchmark for steering feel.

brake_confidence.value: Stock brakes are adequate for track use given the light weight. Front: 11.1-inch ventilated discs. Rear: 10.2-inch solid discs. ABS available. Light weight means less thermal stress on brakes. Upgrade to larger rotors for heavy track use.

sound_signature.value: VTEC screaming to 8,400 RPM is an event. The B18C5 produces a high-pitched wail above VTEC that sounds like a racing engine. The intake howl at high RPM is distinctive. With an aftermarket exhaust, the sound becomes even more aggressive. The sound is integral to the driving experience.

comfort_notes.value: Firm Recaro seats provide excellent support but limited comfort on long drives. Minimal sound deadening makes highway cruising noisy. Stiff suspension transmits road imperfections. Air conditioning works but is not powerful. Daily drivable for enthusiasts but not comfortable in the traditional sense.

track_readiness.source: Factory setup is track-capable out of box

track_readiness_notes.value: The ITR is track-ready from the factory. LSD, adequate brakes, stiff suspension, and excellent cooling make it capable of repeated track sessions. Consider brake fluid upgrade and fresh pads for heavy track use. Stock cooling system is adequate.
track_readiness_notes.source: Track day experience, Honda Challenge racers

value: 8,400 RPM redline - one of highest for production cars
Best FWD chassis ever made - benchmark handling
Collector status - values continue to appreciate
Theft magnet - ITRs are frequently stolen
Finding stock examples - most have been modified
Age - all are 23+ years old now
Limited power - 195hp modest by modern standards
Spartan interior - not comfortable for daily use

not_ideal_for.value: Budget buyers—these are expensive now. Those seeking comfort—the ITR is spartan. Power seekers—195hp is modest by modern standards. Daily commuters—firm ride and high theft risk. Those without secure storage.

ideal_owner.value: Honda enthusiasts who appreciate the B18C5 and understand what makes the ITR special. Collectors recognizing the ITR's historical significance. Drivers who value chassis balance, steering feel, and engagement over straight-line speed. Those with secure storage and appropriate insurance.

value.title: VTEC Engine
value.description: The B18C5 is one of Honda's greatest engines. 195hp from 1.8L NA, 108 hp/liter. 8,400 RPM redline. Hand-ported head.

value.title: Chassis Excellence
value.description: The DC2 Type R chassis is the FWD benchmark. Double-wishbone suspension, seam-welded body, perfect weight distribution.

value.title: Light Weight
value.description: 2,577 lbs enables remarkable agility. Power-to-weight ratio makes every horsepower count.

value.title: Honda Reliability
value.description: B-series engines are legendary for reliability. With proper maintenance, these run 300K+ miles.

value.title: Collector Status
value.description: Values have appreciated significantly. Recognized as an automotive milestone.

value.title: Extreme Prices
value.description: Clean examples now cost $50-100K+. Low-mile examples exceed $200K. Entry fee is prohibitive.

value.title: Theft Target
value.description: ITRs are stolen constantly for parts and whole. Essential to have Kill switches, GPS tracker, and secure storage.

value.title: Finding Stock Examples
value.description: Most have been modified. Original, unmodified cars command huge premiums and are rare.

value.title: Age
value.description: All examples are 23+ years old. Rubber deteriorates, trim fades, and maintenance needs increase.

essence.value: The front-wheel-drive benchmark—a high-revving B18C5 in a lightweight, seam-welded chassis that proved FWD can be genuinely engaging. The ITR represents Honda's uncompromising approach to performance.

tagline.source: Captures the essence of the car

notes.value: The holy grail Honda. 8,400 RPM VTEC perfection. First Type R sold in America. Only ~4,000 sold in US 1997-2001.

hero_blurb.value: The Acura Integra Type R defined what a front-wheel-drive sports car could be. With its hand-built 195hp B18C5 engine screaming to 8,400 RPM, seam-welded chassis, and uncompromising focus on driving purity, the ITR proved that FWD cars could deliver genuine engagement. Only about 4,000 were sold in America, and today they're recognized as one of Honda's greatest achievements.

buyers_summary.value: Buy the most stock, best-documented example possible. Championship White is most desirable color. Verify VIN and history carefully—theft recovery cars and clones exist. Pre-purchase inspection by Honda specialist essential. Budget for secure storage and specialty insurance. Prices unlikely to decrease.

recommendation_highlight.value: Prioritize documentation and originality over low price. Stock examples appreciate faster than modified ones.

value.reason: First year, most desirable for collectors. Championship White only. Lowest production numbers.
Final years with all refinements. Championship White and Phoenix Yellow available.

years_to_avoid.source: 1999 model year not offered in US market

value.reason: Not sold in US market. Any 1999 ITR in US is either JDM import or incorrectly titled.

recommended_years_note.value: All US-market years (1997, 1998, 2000, 2001) are desirable. 1997 is most collectible as first year. 2000-2001 have minor refinements and Phoenix Yellow option.

value.name: Stock Configuration
value.reason: Unmodified cars are worth 2-3x more than modified examples.

value.name: Championship White
value.reason: Most iconic color. Commands premium. Available all years.

value.name: Documentation
value.reason: Original window sticker, service records, ownership history significantly increase value.

value.name: Phoenix Yellow
value.reason: Rarer color, only available 2000-2001. Desirable alternative to white.

value.name: Low Mileage
value.reason: Under 50K miles commands significant premium. Under 20K enters six-figure territory.
Confirm VIN matches title, door sticker, and engine bay. Theft/clones exist.
Test VTEC engagement at 6,100 RPM. Should be distinct change in character.
All cylinders should be within spec and even.
Limited-slip differential should transfer power evenly. Test in parking lot.
Examine rear wheel wells, rocker panels, and rear hatch area.
Factory seam welds visible in engine bay. Verify present and undisturbed.
Championship White is prone to yellowing. Check for respray signs.

ppi_recommendations.value: Pre-purchase inspection by Honda specialist essential. Recommend shops with Type R experience. Compression test, leak-down test, and thorough inspection of VTEC system. Check for signs of theft recovery or clone builds. Expect to pay $200-400 for comprehensive PPI.

predecessors.source: GS-R was the performance Integra before Type R

value: Honda Civic Type R FK8 (spiritual successor)
successors.source: RSX replaced Integra; FK8 is modern Type R

direct_competitors.source: Period competitors in hot hatch segment

value.name: Acura NSX NA1
value.reason: More power, RWD, mid-engine. Honda's halo car.

value.name: BMW M3 E36
value.reason: More power, RWD, similar era.

value.name: Acura RSX Type-S
value.reason: More affordable, newer, still engaging.

value.name: Honda Civic Si (FG2)
value.reason: Much more affordable, similar Honda character.

value.name: Lotus Elise
value.reason: Similarly pure, lightweight, engaging.

value.name: Mazda Miata NA
value.reason: Lightweight, engaging, driver-focused.

value.notes: Seals wear over time causing oil leaks and VTEC issues. Straightforward replacement.
Honda distributors fail with age. Replacement resolves misfires and starting issues.
Area around tailgate near roof is prone to corrosion. Inspect carefully.
Rubber trim warps and fades. OEM parts increasingly scarce.
Replace every 90K miles. Interference engine - belt failure = engine damage.

ownership_cost_notes.value: Honda reliability keeps running costs low. Major expenses are timing belt/water pump (~$600 every 90K miles), specialty insurance ($1,500-3,000/year), and secure storage. Parts increasingly scarce for trim pieces but mechanical parts still available. Budget for appreciating asset care.

parts_availability.source: Mechanical parts still available; trim scarce

parts_notes.value: Mechanical parts (engine, transmission, suspension) still available through Honda and aftermarket. Nengun, Japan-based suppliers, and The Integra Hub specialize in ITR parts. Trim pieces (window moldings, interior) increasingly scarce and expensive. Some items no longer available new.

dealer_vs_independent.source: Acura dealers lack specialized knowledge; independents preferred

dealer_notes.value: Most Acura dealers no longer have technicians familiar with the DC2 Type R. Recommend independent Honda specialists with B-series experience. Several shops specialize in ITR maintenance and restoration.

diy_notes.value: Basic maintenance (oil changes, brakes, fluid flushes) is straightforward for DIYers. Timing belt requires moderate mechanical skill. VTEC solenoid service is accessible. Extensive documentation and tutorials available online. Honda-Tech forums are invaluable resource.

value.original: 3 years/36,000 miles bumper-to-bumper; 5 years/60,000 miles powertrain
value.current: N/A - all vehicles out of warranty

resale_reputation.value: The Integra Type R has exceptional resale reputation. Values have appreciated significantly over the past decade, with clean examples increasing 200-300% in value. Market demand remains strong, and trend shows continued appreciation. One of the best automotive investments of the past 20 years.

value.notes: Stock cooling system handles repeated track sessions. Aluminum radiator upgrade recommended for sustained high-RPM use.
Light weight reduces brake stress. Stock brakes adequate for most track use. High-temp brake fluid and quality pads recommended.

value.reason: Stock fluid boils under hard use. Upgrade to DOT 4 racing fluid.
Hawk HP+ or similar for improved bite and fade resistance.
Honda recommends 10W-30 for track use.
Start at 32-35 psi, adjust based on tire temps.
Adjustable height and damping for optimal setup.
Reduces understeer.
Larger rotors for sustained hard braking.
Safety and chassis stiffness.

market_commentary.value: The ITR market has matured from enthusiast car to collectible. Clean, stock examples are the most valuable. Modified cars sell for less unless professionally built. The market peaked in 2021-2022 but remains strong. Japanese domestic market (JDM) ITRs are also in demand as federally legal 25+ year imports.

owner_notes_long.value: The ITR rewards owners who understand its character. It wants to be revved, and the magic happens above 6,000 RPM. Daily driving is possible but not ideal—the firm ride and high theft risk make it better suited as a weekend car. Storage should be secure and climate-controlled. Join the community—ITR owners are passionate and helpful. Documentation is everything for resale value.

aftermarket_scene_notes.value: The Honda/Acura aftermarket is massive. B-series engines have decades of development. Tuning support from Hondata, KTuner, and others. Performance parts from Skunk2, Toda, Spoon, and dozens of manufacturers. The ITR community is active and supportive, with extensive documentation online.

community_strength.source: One of the strongest enthusiast communities

community_notes.value: The ITR community is extremely active and dedicated. Multiple forums, Facebook groups, and regional clubs exist. Annual events like ITR Expo bring owners together. Knowledge sharing is excellent—almost any question has been answered somewhere online.

value.name: Integra Type R Club of America
Integra Type R Expo
value.description: Annual gathering organized by ITRCA with track days and social events.

value.quote: The Integra Type R is the finest front-wheel-drive car ever made. Period.
Honda's masterpiece of lightweight engineering and high-revving excitement.

value.title: The Evolution Of The Acura Integra
Why The Integra Type R Is So Special

value.quote: The ITR is the greatest FWD car ever built. Nothing else comes close to this level of engagement.
The Integra Type R taught a generation what a front-wheel-drive car could be.

expert_consensus_summary.value: Universal acclaim as the greatest front-wheel-drive car ever made. Critics praise the high-revving engine, exceptional chassis, and pure driving experience. The only consistent criticism is that values have risen beyond most budgets.

cta_copy.value: Experience Honda's ultimate front-wheel-drive sports car.

value.notes: Basic bolt-ons with tune. Keeps NA character.
Significant gains while remaining NA. Higher redline possible.
Maximum NA power. Some go turbo at this level.

stockValvetrain.notes: Stock valvetrain safe to ~8,800 RPM with proper springs

weaknesses: Limited power potential NA vs turbo cars
community_tips: Keep it NA for authenticity and value
Use Honda OEM parts where possible
